Title: [ANN][ICO] ðŸ’° Javvy - More than a crypto exchange & wallet combined! ðŸ’°
Body: Hello,  Sorry for the delay in responding as we've been moving offices and getting set up...     We do not know how current exchanges handle their settlements, but they likely have an automated process that works with banking API callbacks after a user adds a bank account (a potential risk for the customer). However, they likely do not handle one-off transactions that are initiated without "having a bank account on file". That is what this patent covers, so that we can make it "optional" for users to store a bank account on file.  Regardless, this method has not been patented, so we patented it more for our protection. The goal is to ensure that patent trolls and the big banks (currently filing a lot of patents in crypto, because they want to centralize it) don't try to cut off our ability to automate payments.  Cheers,  Brandon

Body: There are many aspects about the wallet tech that make it more secure. But, yes, being a non web-based application is the biggest step. There are already other crypto wallets that are not web-based, but there is much more to being secure than those wallets address. Also, the Javvy wallet will educate while providing options for 2-factor authentication (methods outside of mobile 2FA, for maximum security on mobile as well).  Our wallet also encrypts everything on the device (some popular crypto wallets do not), and malware/ransomware cannot bypass the 2FA. There are other security features as well, but we must keep some things under wraps, as we've already basically laid out most of our plans publicly. These have already been used by Coinbase, and others, as a template or guide on how to improve their offerings. So, some things we keep to ourselves and rely on users to review our profiles (background and expertise) to see that we are very qualified to deliver this much needed solution for crypto users everywhere.  Fortunately, some of the biggest benefits of the Javvy wallet are going to protected by patent.  Note: The smoke-and-mirrors part of ICOs is that very few ICOs really spell out what they are doing on the micro level. They just claim they will address a need, in a market with huge potential, and then they ask for trust (even if their backgrounds are not related). However, nearly all successful ICOs already have massive funding lined up (at huge discounts for their "friends"), generate buzz around the ICO, and then hope that some additional people buy in (where the later users [the crowd] pay significant premium). With Javvy, we are doing it all the hard way. We worked on detailed documentation, patent filings, product development BEFORE outside funding, extremely expensive and detailed financials/projections, and working diligently to earn the crypto community's trust. We believe that THIS is the way it should be and that everyone will appreciate our honesty, integrity, and transparency.

Author: Javvy
Title: [ANN][ICO] ðŸ’° Javvy - More than a crypto exchange & wallet combined! ðŸ’°
Body: I almost covered and discussed "priority dates" in the video, but we decided to keep it simpler and shorter. That video has not been released yet, but since it doesn't cover that point; I'll answer here.  So, the way it works is that filing a "patent pending" gives you a "priority date" on the day it is filed. There are no prior patents that would override our patent, but there is a chance that another "patent pending", filed prior to ours, would conflict and have an earlier priority date. There is no way to know, until one is published, but we feel that it is unlikely. Most of the patents being filed are in regards to settling securities using a custodial account (depository for internal settlements) or are related to blockchain innovations.  I doubt that others were focused on the methods in our patents, because "atomic swaps" did not exist, meaning the value was limited (e.g. required 3rd-parties that charge a fee). However, I had the foresight to know that it would be possible one day (and bitcoin to ethereum atomic swapping is already possible now, much sooner than I anticipated). As a result, we will be able to use these virtually free methods and avoid using even Shapeshift (fee-based).

Title: [ANN][ICO] ðŸ’° Javvy - More than a crypto exchange & wallet combined! ðŸ’°
Body: Sure. I would be happy to give some insight into the dev process and the overall obstacles facing our startup...  Building a crypto wallet for a single platform, from open-source, would likely take 1 month to get working.  Adding in a focus on streamlining navigation and building an attractive and intuitive user interface usually takes months, due to all the feedback, opinions, and focus group testing.  Then, adding in native development for each platform (increased performance, better UI/UX, consistency, reliability) takes another 1-2 months.  We also added quite a few advanced features, such as support for ERC20 tokens (starting with the Javvy token, of course! ), Bitcoin Cash, etc. These would typically add another 1-2 months of testing to get fully operational.  Lastly, a LOT of testing and refining is necessary.  Now, to put that 6-12 months of work into perspective: Back in June/July, we decided to charge forward with this project, on the basis that we would be able to fund it via an ICO. Unfortunately, that gave us precious little time to find qualified blockchain/wallet developers, create all of the documentation, build the website, push ahead with marketing, and do everything that is required of a startup. So, we've basically squeezed more than a year of work into a few months. We were able to scale our wallet dev team up to several very knowledgeable and capable people, but it still takes time.  Everyone on our team (23 people and growing) have done a spectacular job! Even though we wanted to release the prototype prior to the ICO, it was an unrealistic expectation. That said, we still hoped to release a working prototype by 10.14.2017 (yesterday).  Now, our lead wallet dev says he currently expects to meet a 10.21.2017 release date, provided no major obstacles arise.  We are planning to take a screen share of the wallet prototype in action and share a "sneak peek" in the next few days. Stay tuned!

Body: Hello,  Let's clarify that Katie meant the terms of "registration" and "verification" to be synonymous... Many people might consider "Registration" to mean giving out an email or signing up in order to download, etc. There is no "registration" required in order to use our wallet. The wallet download, once available, may be done anonymously or installed directly from a mobile app store (not really anonymous because the carrier knows who you are but we do not). As far as VERIFICATION, our focus on regulations abides by the most restrictive of country-specific and global policies.  So the answer is different for different people.  For instance, every user may use the wallet's send, receive, and convert functions without registering OR being verified.  When buying or selling cryptos/tokens, the following applies:  IF the user is a US citizen, they may be verified instantly by their US bank account and have a low, but reasonable, limit IF the user is a non-US citizen OR is a US citizen wanting higher limits or without a US bank account, then ID verification would be necessary*  *Using our rapid ID verification system (usually instant upon scan or upload of photos of proper documents).  Does that clarify things a bit?  Cheers,  Brandon

Body: The soft cap is set to 5,000 ETH. Below that amount and all contributors will be refunded.  The hard cap is set to 2,000,000 ETH. This number was chosen as an arbitrarily high limit, not the amount of any goal.  Quote from: PENSCoin on October 15, 2017, 02:56:32 AM Very interesting project but why such a large amount of the project? How will the team spend big money?  Following onto the prior answer, the 2,000,000 ETH limit is not a goal but rather an arbitrarily high limit to allow for anyone who wants to contribute, to have an equal opportunity to participate. This way, we avoid the "fastest clicker" frenzy or the "too low gas" types of issues that may end up leaving many behind. Instead, everyone who wants in, during this short ICO contribution period, will be able to get in. The way the ICO is structured, coins are minted only based on the amount of ETH contributed, and no JVY tokens will ever be minted again.  For example: So, if 5,000 ETH (the minimum for successful ICO) is contributed, then 2,500,000 tokens will be minted. This finite allotment results in scarcity. If more ETH is contributed, there will be more tokens but, after much discussion, we felt that the demand will justify and offset having less scarcity.  As for "how will the team spend big money", please see our road-map (image link below) for a vision of how large contributions will be spent.    What do you think of that plan?  Best regards,  Brandon

Author: Javvy
Title: [ANN][ICO] ðŸ’° Javvy - More than a crypto exchange & wallet combined! ðŸ’°
Body: Hello. Basically, yes.  Keep in mind that this is a "wish list" goal, because the funding and time required would be quite high. However, in the event that we raise the necessary funds OR the Javvy crypto solution revenues grow quickly enough, we would begin to stockpile physical gold and/or establish a relationship with a major bulk supplier (possibly a mine with guaranteed contractual pricing). Then, if a Javvy user wanted to trade for gold, once the payment was accepted and verified; the physical gold would be shipped (fully insured, up to shipping limits) to the requested address.  In this case, we envision that some sort of verification would be required (to help offset fraud and AML/KYC policies), so the address would need to match what was verified and kept on file. This feature gets us very excited about the possibilities!  I do not yet know if we would pay users for gold, though, as it would be costly and time-consuming to test all incoming gold for authenticity. So, this part of the process would need to be further considered and worked out. Therefore, it is possible that we would not be providing liquidity in the gold markets but rather a means to acquire physical gold.  To clarify our long-term vision, we would love to see the Javvy wallet be the only app anyone will ever need to buy, sell, and manage everything from cryptocurrencies to tokens to credit cards (via API integrations) to bank accounts (also via API integrations) to certain commodities (such as gold). We do realize that this is a very lofty goal, which is why no solution like this exists. However, our team is very capable and "just because it hasn't been done before, doesn't mean it cannot be done!" ;-)

Body: Hello Luigi21,  Ironically, I actually just stumbled across Eidoo a few days ago. They apparently started their site and campaign around the same time we did. I took about 15 minutes to review their pitch, because it does sound similar at first glance.  The biggest differences are:  1. They state a lot of the same goals but they do not have a regulatory focus, so they will have major difficulties attracting customers in geographic regions with strict regulations (such as the USA, Russia, China, soon-to-be EU, etc). This may also lead to them being shut down or being put under pressure, prior to their late 2018 goal to add the regulatory component. Other than that, this is likely the closest project out there claiming to deliver what Javvy will deliver. So, you are very astute to have found them and compared the two of us.  2. I could not find any convincing information on their team. Most would agree that a strong team is the #1 foundation for a pitch such as this. Anyone can have a great idea, but it's important to back it with the right team. Compare that to our team's extremely relevant and focused expertise here: https://javvy.com/#javvyteam  3. Eidoo does have the same focus of wanting to be a consolidated wallet solution, but they will be limited to buy/sell for their exchange supported cryptocurrencies. Most exchanges support only bitcoin, with a very few that support Ethereum and/or Litecoin. However, Javvy's patent pending 62558597 (https://javvy.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/javvy-patent-62558597_raw-format.pdf) will allow Javvy to serve buy/sell orders to ALL major cryptocurrencies, and approved tokens, on the day of our official release (Q1-Q2 of 2018*).  4. It may seem minor to most, but their domain is eidoo.io and they do not own eidoo.com, which is a spammy parked page that installs malware. As a result, I do not think the security savvy users out there will take that project seriously, unless they receive a lot of funding and use that to acquire the spammy .com domain.  *Note: We are planning to release our wallet prototype prior to the official ICO launch, but it will not support buy/sell capability, as that is a huge component that is a main reason we are raising funds in the equity fundraise and the ICO. I personally invested over $350,000 into this project, so far, just to get it to where it is now; but we need a lot more in order to change the face of global finance. Body: Javvy will likely launch its own marketplace (a maker-taker system) similar to most crypto exchanges targeted to tech-savvy and high-volume traders. However, the real goal of Javvy is to bring crypto to the mainstream by making the whole process simple and seamless for users.  Javvy will be "the easy button" for crypto.  So, the marketplace will not be the focus, as we will likely integrate several marketplaces (for liquidity and arbitrage purposes), but that would be the only "centralized" element. Everything else will be installed on the user's device (desktop or mobile), with all backups, security, and private keys on the device itself (no possibility of theft from any web-based storage, like with existing exchanges and online crypto wallets). We also plan for the Javvy wallet to support 2FA (2-Factor Authentication) and hardware wallets, so that users are protected against malware and ransomware attacks also.

Body: I'm curious as to why would you be suspicious of advisors who are compensated other than tokens? I think that having advisors who simply lend their name (or who's persona is used without their knowledge, such as Vitalik Buterin being listed on the TenX ICO) is not as good as having an advisor who is truly vested in the company and the success of the venture. That means that they should be investors, own equity, promote the ICO as social proof, and/or be willing to join the team in a more hands-on capacity.  Javvy advisors are compensated the same as with any company, regardless of ICO.  Some Javvy advisors work for tokens only.  Some of our advisors, such as Toshendra Sharma (Toshblocks), also provide specific services. So, Toshendra's team provided the ICO smart contracts and spent over a month customizing their powerful, audited, and proven ICO scripts for the Javvy ICO. Therefore, they were paid a combination of CASH and a future token allotment. It is only fair that more than tokens be given, in cases such as these that require significant up-front work.  We sourced our networks for advisors, but we also opened up advisor roles to exceptional freelancers. In those cases, some advisors are paid hourly in the case that we want to get to know them first. The goal here is to determine if they are a good fit as advisor or to convert to a permanent position with the team. If the freelancer doesn't work out, then we part ways. If they do work out, then they will be offered a compensation package that will include a base salary and tokens.
